block.p: James Traub's exploration of why even good schools can't help children overcome the disadvantages of inner-city poverty and chaos (Jan. 16) is also a powerful argument for expanding residential schools for children from abusive or neglectful homes and violent neighborhoods. Residential education is not a cheap alternative -- approximately $25,000 per year per student, including school, food, clothing, shelter and after-school activities. But as Traub writes, ''ghetto children need an enveloping environment that is secure and nourishing, as the streets and often the home itself are not.''
